text: This unit will teach you the most basic buiding blocks of any website or web application. That is HTML.
heading: 1.1 Basics of HTML
text: HTML is the basic building block of most websites. HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language, and is what defines the content and structure of a webpage.
To get started, open your text editor and create a new file. Call it index.html.
Paste the following code into your textfile, and save it.
code:
## ## ##
#T#Website title ## ## #T#
A heading #T#
Some text here ## ##
text: The first line #!!# specifies that this is an HTML document.
HTML syntax is made up of tags, that are enclosed in #!<>!#
Most tags need to be closed by having a #!/!# in the closing tag. As you can see from the example, the #!!# tag is closed by #!!#. That is the same for both #!h1!# and #!p!#.

Enclosed in the #!html!# tags is all the HTML content for this page. The #!head!# tag contains metadata about the website such as the website #!title!# which you see in your browser tab. The #!body!# specifies the content that is visible on the webpage.
#!h1!# is a header, and #!p!# specifies a paragraph. There are many elements in HTML. The next section covers some of them.
This is a very basic HTML file. Open the file in a browser to see its output.
heading: 1.2 Basics of HTML
text: One of the most important structures in HTML are headers. As you saw in the previous example, h1 created a big header. There are 6 levels of headers in HTML. They are shown below.
code:
## ## ## #T#
Heading 1 #T#
Heading 2 #T#
Heading 3 #T#
Heading 4 #T#
Heading 5 #T#
Heading 6 ## ##
text: Another important HTML element is #!div!#, which lets you define different sections. Generally, different portions of the webpage are split into different divs. The following example shows two different divs that correspond to different sections. We also show one more element, #!hr!#, which defines a horizontal line / break.
code:
## ## ## #T#
#TT#
Section 1 #TT#
This is the first section #T# #T# #T#
#TT#
Section 2 #TT#
This is the second section #T# ## ##
text: HTML allows you to have lists. There are two types: ordered lists #!ol!# and unordered lists #!ul!#. Inside the list, you specify list items using the tag #!li!#.
code:
## ## ## #T# #TT#
First item #TT#
Second item #TT#
Third item #T# #T# #TT#
First item #TT#
Second item #TT#
Third item #T# ## ##
heading: 1.3 Input Types
text: HTML also allows having #!input!#. To have input, it is specified inside a #!form!#. You can create different forms for different input groups and have as many inputs in a form as you like.
To specify the type of input, you must specify the property #!type!#. These are some examples of types available in HTML.

list.item: text: Allows a regular text input
checkbox: Adds a checkbox that can be checked or unchecked
radio: Adds a radio button which only allows one selection at a time
date: Allows specifying a date input
reset: Button that clears the form

text: You can also add descriptions to your inputs by wrapping the input in a #!label!# tag.
Here is an example that uses all of those input types:
The radio button input uses the property name to link the two radio buttons together. As you can see, only one of them can be selected at a time, as only one value should be present.
